coredata.dc:title: Ionic-liquid-containing polymer interlayer modified PEO-based electrolyte for stable high-voltage solid-state lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Cai, Dan
Wu, Xianzhang
Xiang, Jiayuan
Li, Min
Su, Han
Qi, Xinhong
Wang, Xiuli
Xia, Xinhui
Gu, Changdong
Tu, Jiangping
coredata.dc:description: Polyethylene oxide (PEO) based solid electrolyte has gained widespread interests owing to its excellent processability, acceptable ionic conductivity and low interfacial resistance toward electrodes. However, the extremely poor compatibility between PEO-based electrolyte and high-voltage cathode restricts its application in high-energy-density batteries, and recent researches indicate that it is also unstable to the Li anode. In this work, a stable ionic-liquid-containing poly(vinylidenefluoride-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP)-based electrolyte (IPL) with high ionic conductivity is engineered as an interlayer in PEO-based solid-state batteries, and the experimental results demonstrate that the IPL interlayer can effectively suppress the interfacial side reactions and helps to form a stable interface between PEO-based solid electrolyte and LiCoO2 (LCO) cathode under high voltage. Moreover, the interlayer can enable stable Li stripping and plating for over 1000 h at 0.1 mA cm−2, exhibiting an excellent stability against the Li anode. Therefore, the LCO/Li cells assembled with the IPL interlayer modified PEO-based electrolyte show high discharge capacity of 144.3 mAh g−1 and 169.7 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C under different voltage of 4.3 V and 4.5 V, and the capacity retention is 85.9% and 82.7% after 100 cycles, respectively. This study provides a novel idea for constructing high-performance PEO-based high-voltage solid-state Li batteries.

Ionic-liquid-containing polymer interlayer
High-voltage cathode
Solid-state batteries

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Schematic illustration of the sandwich like IPI electrolyte. Surface morphologies of the PLL electrolyte (b) and IPI electrolyte (c). (d) Cross-sectional SEM image of IPI composite electrolyte. (e) XRD patterns of LLZTO and the prepared PLL electrolyte. (f) TG curves of IPI electrolyte, the inset shows the magnified part.

(a) Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of IPL and PLL electrolyte at room temperature, the inset shows the equivalent circuit. (b) The Li+ conductivity of both layers measured at different temperatures. (c) Arrhenius plots of IPL and PLL electrolyte. (d) Linear sweep voltammetry curves of IPL and PLL electrolyte between 2.5 V and 5.0 V using Li/electrolyte/carbon cells. (e) The calculated HOMO and LUMO energy levels of PEO, LiTFSI, PVDF-HFP and PYR13TFSI, inset: the corresponding chemical structural formulas.

(a) Voltage profiles of Li/IPL/Li and Li/PLL/Li symmetric cells under 0.1 mA cm−2 at room temperature. Magnified voltage profiles: (b) (c) Li/IPL/Li cell in 450–470 h and 980–1000 h, respectively, (d) Li/PLL/Li cell in 450–470 h.

The electrochemical performance of LCO/IPI/Li and LCO/PLL/Li cells at room temperature: Rate performance from 0.2 C to 1 C under different cutoff voltages of (a) 4.3 V and (b) 4.5 V; Cycling performance at 0.2 C under different cutoff voltages of (c) 4.3 V and (d) 4.5 V. (e) Schematic diagram of the fabricated LCO/IPI/Li cell. The corresponding charge and discharge curves of (f) (g) LCO/IPI/Li cells and (h)(i) LCO/PLL/Li cells at different cycles under cutoff voltages of 4.3 V and 4.5 V. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of LCO/Li cells with (j) IPI electrolyte and (k) PLL electrolyte before and after 100 cycles at 4.5 V.

SEM and TEM images of LCO cathode before and after 100 cycles with different electrolytes: (a–c) Fresh LCO, (d–f) IPI electrolyte at 4.3 V, (g–i) IPI electrolyte at 4.5 V, (j–l) PLL electrolyte at 4.3 V, (m–o) PLL electrolyte at 4.5 V.

SEM images and the corresponding XPS spectra of Li anode after 100 cycles with different electrolytes: (a–d) IPI electrolyte at 4.3 V, (e–h) IPI electrolyte at 4.5 V, (i–l) PLL electrolyte at 4.3 V, (m–p) PLL electrolyte at 4.5 V. The inset shows the corresponding photographs of Li anode.

head.ce:title: Ionic-liquid-containing polymer interlayer modified PEO-based electrolyte for stable high-voltage solid-state lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Polyethylene oxide (PEO) based solid electrolyte has gained widespread interests owing to its excellent processability, acceptable ionic conductivity and low interfacial resistance toward electrodes. However, the extremely poor compatibility between PEO-based electrolyte and high-voltage cathode restricts its application in high-energy-density batteries, and recent researches indicate that it is also unstable to the Li anode. In this work, a stable ionic-liquid-containing poly(vinylidenefluoride-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP)-based electrolyte (IPL) with high ionic conductivity is engineered as an interlayer in PEO-based solid-state batteries, and the experimental results demonstrate that the IPL interlayer can effectively suppress the interfacial side reactions and helps to form a stable interface between PEO-based solid electrolyte and LiCoO2 (LCO) cathode under high voltage. Moreover, the interlayer can enable stable Li stripping and plating for over 1000 h at 0.1 mA cm−2, exhibiting an excellent stability against the Li anode. Therefore, the LCO/Li cells assembled with the IPL interlayer modified PEO-based electrolyte show high discharge capacity of 144.3 mAh g−1 and 169.7 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C under different voltage of 4.3 V and 4.5 V, and the capacity retention is 85.9% and 82.7% after 100 cycles, respectively. This study provides a novel idea for constructing high-performance PEO-based high-voltage solid-state Li batteries.

ce:section.ce:para: Considering the need for improved safety and high energy density in the energy storage field, solid-state Li metal batteries have aroused widespread interest for many years [1,2]. Solid-state electrolyte is the key part of solid-state batteries, and plays dual roles in separating electrodes (cathode and anode) and conducting Li+ [3]. Due to no volatile liquid electrolyte in solid-state batteries, therefore introducing solid-state electrolyte greatly simplifies the structure of the batteries. Furthermore, solid-state electrolyte possesses many advantages such as non-flammability, stability and non-leakage that can meet the needs of the future batteries [4,5]. Lithium (Li) metal (−3.04 V vs SHE, 3860 mAh g−1) is regarded as the most promising anode [6–8]. However, the practical application of Li anode are hindered by severe side reaction and uncontrollable Li dendrites growth in conventional liquid electrolyte, which may bring about potential safety hazard in use [9–11]. Replacing the liquid electrolyte with solid-state electrolyte is regarded as the most effective way to solve the above problems, and the energy density of energy storage system can be further promoted by the application of Li anode [12].

Over the past decades, tremendous efforts have been devoted to study new solid-state electrolyte. Up till now, there are two main types of electrolytes [13]: inorganic solid electrolytes (ISEs) (Li10GeP2S12 (LGPS) [14], Li0.34La0.56TiO3 (LLTO) [15], Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) [16], Li1.3Al0.3Ti1.7(PO4)3 (LATP) [17], Li3InCl6 [18] etc.) and solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) (poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) [19], poly(acrylonitrile) (PAN) [20], poly(vinylidenefluoride-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP) [21], poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO) [22,23], etc.). In addition to their use as solid electrolytes, polymers have long been used in liquid lithium-ion batteries, where polymer-based binders and separators are essential components [24,25]. Generally, the Li+ conductivity of ISEs at room temperature is high (>10−3 S cm−1). However, the intrinsic brittleness and the poor interfacial contact between ISEs and electrodes limit its practical application [26]. Moreover, even though numerous efforts have been made, the fabrication of thin ISEs still remains challenging [3], and there is no relatively facile and low-cost method for preparation of ISEs that can enable the large-scale production at present. In contrast, SPEs or composite electrolytes generally exhibit superior flexibility, excellent processability, inexpensive cost as well as low interfacial resistance toward electrodes [27,28].

Among them, PEO-based solid electrolytes have been extensively investigated due to its strong ability in dissolving Li salts and relatively low glass transition temperature since its first discovery as ionic conductor in 1973 by Wright and co-workers [29,30]. But the cathode materials that couple with PEO-based electrolytes are mainly confined to LiFePO4 instead of high-voltage cathodes such as LiCoO2 because the decomposition of PEO electrolyte was reported to start at 3.8 V (vs Li/Li+) [31]. Moreover, the highly oxidative Co4+ generated by deeply delithiated LiCoO2 cathode at high voltage can accelerate the decomposition of PEO electrolyte, and the accumulation of byproducts at the LCO/electrolyte interfaces usually results in high interfacial resistance, causing rapid deterioration of battery performance [32–34]. These issues seriously restrict the further improvement of energy density in PEO-based solid-state batteries, as a high cutoff voltage can extend voltage plateau and increase the specific capacity for LCO cathode. To make the PEO-based electrolyte compatible with LCO cathode at high voltage, various strategies have been proposed. These strategies can be divided into the following two categories: (1) The first method is to design multilayer electrolyte by introducing a PAN-based interlayer which is stable to LCO at high voltage [35], or to add different lithium salts into the PEO matrix in different layers to modify the HOMO and LUMO of PEO electrolyte [36]. (2) The second approach is to coat the LCO particles with sable materials such as LATP [37,38], LAGP [39], polymer (PECA) [40] and accompany with distinct binders [41]. Despite tremendous efforts, few of researches are cycled at cutoff voltage as high as 4.5 V, and the cyclic performance of PEO-based solid-state batteries with LCO cathode is still not satisfying.

In previous reports, PEO-based electrolytes were generally thought to possess good stability toward Li anode [35,42]. However, recent researches suggest that the parasitic reaction between PEO electrolyte and highly reductive Li is inevitable and serious. For instance, Sheng and co-workers found that PEO-LiTFSI electrolyte turned into heterogeneously porous state after Li deposition and observed the mosaic interface between PEO and Li anode by Cryo-transmission electron microscopy (cryo-TEM) [43]. In another study, Mirsakiyeva and co-workers investigated the interfacial chemistry between PEO and Li by means of theoretical calculation (DFT) and found that they were inclined to react under a strong thermodynamic driving force [44]. Therefore, on the basis of above cognitions, interlayer designing is considered to be an effective strategy for improving the interfacial stability between PEO-based electrolytes and electrodes, including high-voltage LCO cathode and Li anode simultaneously.

Ionic liquids generally possess good properties, and introducing them as plasticizer of gel polymer electrolytes can increase the ionic conductivity of electrolyte as well as afford sufficient electrochemical window for high-voltage batteries. Therefore, ionic-liquid-containing PVDF-HFP-based electrolytes have been studied for years as they usually possess wide electrochemical windows and high ionic conductivity [45–48]. It has also been demonstrated that this kind of electrolyte displays superior thermal stability and good stability to high-voltage cathode as well as Li anode [49–51]. In this work, we introduced a PVDF-HFP-based interlayer that contains pyrrolidinium-type ionic liquid on the both sides of PEO-based electrolyte and fabricated a sandwich like IPL interlayer modified PEO-based electrolyte (IPI) electrolyte by a simple solution-casting method. To ensure the electrochemical performance of the batteries, the PEO-LLZTO (PLL) composite electrolyte with higher ionic conductivity rather than PEO-LiTFSI polymer electrolyte was chosen as a typical representative of PEO-based electrolytes. The introduced IPL interlayer possesses high ionic conductivity and good electrochemical stability. Moreover, the stability of the IPL interlayer toward Li anode and LCO cathode was also investigated by Li stripping/plating behavior and theoretical calculation (DFT), respectively. The LCO/Li cells with this novel IPI electrolyte show high discharge capacity and superior cyclic stability at voltage of both 4.3 V and 4.5 V. And the excellent electrochemical performance can be attributed to the stable electrolyte/electrode interface, which revealed by various interfacial characterizations such as SEM, TEM and XPS. The comparison between the electrochemical performance of high-voltage LCO/Li cells with PEO-based electrolyte that have been reported so far is shown in Table S1. This multilayered strategy can be applied to all PEO electrolytes and provides a novel sight for constructing high-voltage solid-state Li metal batteries with PEO-based electrolyte.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of PLL and IPI composite electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: A facile solution-casting method was used to prepare all the composite electrolytes. PEO (Mw = 600,000 g/mol, 99%, Aladdin) and lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI, 99%, Aladdin) (EO/Li+ = 16:1) were dissolved in anhydrous acetonitrile (99.99%, Aladdin) first, then 30 wt% LLZTO was added to the transparent solution and dispersed by magnetic stirring for 12 h. After that, the obtained uniform milky mixture was cast on the clean glass plate and dried at 60 °C in vacuum for 24 h to get the PLL electrolyte

An appropriate amount of PVDF-HFP (Mw = 400,000 g/mol, 99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich), LiTFSI and N-methyl-N-propylpyrrolidinium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (PYR13TFSI, 99%, Lanzhou Greenchem ILs) (40:14:46 by weight) were dissolved in dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.9%, Aladdin) and formed a homogeneous solution after magnetic stirring for 12 h. The concentration of PVDF-HFP in DMF is 30 wt%. Then it was cast on the clean glass plate and dried at 60 °C to get the IPL electrolyte. To fabricate the sandwich like IPI (IPL-PLL-IPL) electrolyte, the PEO-LLZTO precursor solution was directly cast on the first layer of IPL electrolyte through the same process, then another IPL electrolyte layer was cast on the other side of the PLL electrolyte. After thoroughly drying, the IPI electrolyte was cut into disks (d = 19 mm) for use. Because the Li salt is very sensitive to moisture, all the preparation was done in the glove box filled with Ar.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of LCO cathode and cathode-supported IPI solid electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: The LiCoO2 powders were heated in vacuum at 80 °C for two days to remove the moisture before use. To make the LCO cathode slurry, 80 wt% LiCoO2 powders, 10 wt% poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) and 10 wt% carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were mixed uniformly by grinding first, and then dispersed in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP, 99.0%, Aladdin) by magnetic stirring for several hours until a homogeneous slurry was obtained. After that, the LCO cathode slurry was cast onto an aluminum foil. The LCO cathode was obtained after NMP was completely removed by heating in vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. The mass loading of LCO cathode is about 1.5 mg cm−2. To prepare the cathode-supported IPI electrolyte, the IPL precursor solution was directly cast on the dry LCO cathode and then dried at 60 °C in vacuum for 12 h, subsequently the PLL electrolyte and another IPL electrolyte layer were added layer by layer, as shown in Fig. S7. For comparison, the LCO cathode supported PLL electrolyte was prepared in the same way.

The morphologies of electrolyte membranes, LCO cathode and Li anode after cycle were characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi SU8010) with an X-ray energy spectrometer unit. Atomic force microscopy (AFM, Bruker Multimode 8) was used to characterize the surface roughness of electrolyte. The Rigaku D/max-2250PC diffractometer (Cu Kα, 10°–80°) was used to collect the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of electrolyte and cycled cathode. To explore the thermal stability of composite electrolyte, the thermos-gravimetric (TG) analysis was performed from room temperature to 700 °C in N2 on a Thermo SDT-Q600 thermal analyser, and the heating rate was 10 °C min−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) were taken on a JEOL 2100F TEM microscope. The Thermo Scientifc K-Alpha + X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Al Kα) was used to get the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results of electrolyte/Li interface.

The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were collected on a Princeton multi-channel electrochemical workstation (10−2–106 Hz), and the AC amplitude was set as 10 mV. To obtain the ionic conductivity (σ) of the prepared electrolytes, the symmetrical stainless blocking cells were assembled, and the ionic conductivity could be obtained from equation: σ = L/RA, where R stands for the bulk resistance, L and A are the thickness of electrolyte and the area of electrode, respectively. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) test was performed in the voltage range of 2.5–6 V on a CHI660E electrochemical workstation to investigate the electrochemical stability of the prepared electrolyte with asymmetrical Li/electrolyte/carbon or Li/electrolyte/stainless cells, and the scanning rate was 0.1 mV s−1. The Land CT3001A battery testing system was used to detect the galvanostatic charge-discharge behavior of symmetrical Li/electrolyte/Li and LCO/electrolyte/Li cells, and the LCO/Li cells were tested in the voltage of 3.0–4.3 V and 3.0–4.5 V with different current density at room temperature.

All calculations were performed using the Gaussian 16 Package. In fact, it is very hard to calculate the whole molecule of polymer as there are many atoms. Therefore, oligomers of PEO and PVDF-HFP consisting of 4 units were adopted to calculate the frontier orbital energy levels. The geometry of the salts and oligomers were optimized using the B3LYP level of theory in conjunction with the 6-311+G (d,p) basis set.

The schematic illustration of the sandwich like IPI electrolyte is shown in Fig. 1 a, and it was fabricated layer by layer by a simple solution-casting method. The IPL electrolyte was introduced as an interlayer to stabilize the interface between PLL electrolyte and high-voltage LCO cathode as well as Li anode simultaneously.

Fig. 1b and c shows the surface morphologies of the PLL electrolyte and IPI electrolyte, respectively. Although slight agglomeration of LLZTO particles can be observed in Fig. 1b, the distribution of LLZTO in PLL composite electrolyte are generally uniform. As a matter of fact, particle agglomeration in composite electrolyte is inevitable once a high proportion of LLZTO particles are added. The corresponding EDS mapping of PLL electrolyte in Fig. S1 also proves its uniformity. After introducing the IPL interlayer, the obtained IPI electrolyte presents a smooth surface (Fig. 1c) as the soft polymer can cover the rough surface of PLL electrolyte caused by raised LLZTO particles. Fig. S2 displays the AFM image of IPI electrolyte, indicating a low surface roughness of about 310 nm. This flat surface of IPI electrolyte can contribute to form an intimate contact between electrolyte and electrodes, which can reduce the interfacial resistance of batteries effectively. Fig. 1d shows the cross-sectional SEM image of the as-prepared IPI electrolyte, it clearly presents a sandwich like structure with thickness of about 70 μm and the different layers of electrolyte can be distinguished easily.

The phases of LLZTO powder and composite electrolyte were investigated by XRD. The XRD results in Fig. 1e indicate that the purchased LLZTO shows a pure and cubic Li7La3Zr2O12 (garnet) phase (PDF#01-080-6076), and the cubic phase remains stable in PLL composite electrolyte. Furthermore, no significant peaks belonging to crystalline PEO are observed. The XRD patterns of IPL and pure PVDF-HFP film are also provided in Fig. S3. The diffraction peaks located at roughly 18, 20 and 39° are assigned to the pure PVDF-HFP film. After adding LiTFSI and ionic liquid (PYR13TFSI), these characteristic peaks disappear or become broader, indicating a decrease in the crystallinity of PVDF-HFP matrix, which is beneficial to the migration of Li+ in electrolyte. The new peak at 12.5° can be ascribed to the incorporated ionic liquid (PYR13TFSI) [49].

Thermo-gravimetric analysis was performed to study the thermal stability of the IPI electrolyte, and the result is shown in Fig. 1f. The evaporation of moisture absorbed by lithium salt leads to a slight weight loss (<2 wt%) below 100 °C. Besides this, the IPI electrolyte does not exhibit obvious decomposition until 225 °C, demonstrating that the IPI electrolyte possesses excellent thermal stability. This result indicates that the designed IPI electrolyte is suitable for practical application and can be applied in various environments.

To evaluate the ionic conductivity of the PLL electrolyte and IPL interlayer, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurements were conducted. As shown in Fig. 2 a, based on the semicircle that represents the bulk impedance of electrolyte, the ionic conductivity of PLL and IPL can be calculated as 1.75 × 10−4 S cm−1 and 3.91 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature, respectively. The ionic conductivity of sandwiched IPI electrolyte is about 2.62 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature (Fig. S4). According to the previous reports, the ionic conductivity of the prepared PLL electrolyte can satisfy the needs of batteries. The IPL interlayer exhibits high ionic conductivity, which can be ascribed to the incorporated ionic liquid and the decreased crystallinity of polymer after introducing ionic liquid and Li salt, as proved by XRD results in Fig. S3. Fig. 2b exhibits the ionic conductivity at different temperatures, and it can be observed that the ionic conductivity of PLL and IPL can reach 5.98 × 10−4 S cm−1 and 10.01 × 10−4 S cm−1 at elevated temperature of 60 °C, respectively. The corresponding Arrhenius plots in Fig. 2c suggest that both PLL and IPL show low activation energy, 0.33 eV and 0.23 eV, respectively. On the basis of Nernst-Einstein equation [52], lower activation energy usually means easier Li+ migration in solid electrolyte. So the IPL interlayer can enable fast Li+ transference between electrodes and PEO-based electrolyte due to its high ionic conductivity and low activation energy, thus contributing to reduce the interfacial resistance. The Li+ transference number of electrolyte could be obtained by the Bruce-Vincent equation [21]. As shown in Fig. S5, the Li+ transference number of PLL and IPL can be calculated as 0.35 and 0.27, respectively. The LLZTO particles in PLL electrolyte can increase Li+ transference number by fixing anions.

The electrochemical stability of electrolyte was investigated by a linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) method. Though many studies have reported that PEO-LiTFSI-garnet composite electrolytes can keep stable above 4.5 V (vs Li/Li+), the recent research indicates that the reported “good electrochemical stability” may be caused by kinetic polarization [37]. On the one hand, the unevenness of the PEO-garnet electrolyte results in poor contact between electrolyte and test electrode, so the obtained LSV results generally present large polarization. On the other hand, the electrode used in LSV test is usually inert electrode such as stainless steel, but the highly reactive carbon is an indispensable part of cathode in a real battery system. Therefore, using the carbon composite electrode instead of smooth stainless steel electrode during LSV test is more reasonable. Fig. 2d shows the linear sweep voltammetry curves of Li/electrolyte/carbon cells. It can be seen that the decomposition starts at 3.8 V (vs Li/Li+) for PLL electrolyte, and this result is consistent with the decomposition voltage of PEO-based electrolyte reported in previous literatures [31,37]. However, the IPL electrolyte does not show violent decomposition until 4.5 V, thus introducing it as an interlayer at the electrolyte/electrode interface provides a possible solution to the problem of poor electrochemical stability of PEO-based electrolytes at high voltage. The linear sweep voltammetry curves of Li/electrolyte/stainless steel cells were also provided in Fig. S6.

To explore the stability of the electrolyte against cathode, theoretical calculation (DFT) was used to investigate the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels of PEO, LiTFSI, PVDF-HFP and PYR13TFSI. The computational details are provided in the experimental section. The HOMO energy reflects the antioxidation properties of electrolytes and can be used to evaluate the stability toward cathode [29,51,53]. As seen in Fig. 2e, all the components of IPL interlayer have lower HOMO than PLL electrolyte, indicating a good stability to cathode at high voltage. It is worth noting that PEO possess a higher HOMO energy than LiTFSI, which means that PEO may start to decompose at electrolyte/cathode interface first.

The role of IPL interlayer in stabilizing the Li anode was also evaluated by the cyclic performance of symmetrical Li-Li cells at room temperature. Fig. 3 a compares the Li+ stripping/plating behavior of Li/IPL/Li and Li/PLL/Li cells at 0.1 mA cm−2. The symmetrical Li-Li cell with IPL presents a smaller initial overpotential of about 75 mV than that of the cell with PLL electrolyte (120 mV) due to its high ionic conductivity and smooth surface, and no obvious increase in overpotential can be observed in Fig. 3b and c throughout the whole cycling (1000 h), demonstrating the uniform Li stripping/plating and stable Li/electrolyte interface. In comparison, the overpotential of cells assembled with PLL electrolyte exhibit a continuous increase during cycling, and then the voltage drops to 0 V at 465 h suddenly (Fig. 3d), indicating the failure of the symmetrical cell due to a short circuit. The increased polarization in Li/PLL/Li cells may be caused by the parasitic reaction between PEO-based electrolyte and highly reductive Li. It is well known that the intrinsic mechanical properties of PEO-based electrolyte are insufficient to inhibit dendrite growth while the PVDF-HFP-based electrolyte usually possesses better mechanical properties. The above results indicate that the ionic-liquid-containing PVDF-HFP electrolyte shows superior stability to Li anode, and introducing it as an interlayer can contribute to stabilize the interface between PEO-based electrolyte and Li anode.

The LCO/electrolyte/Li cells were also assembled to evaluate the electrochemical performance of IPI electrolyte in battery system with high-voltage cathode. Unlike the conventional stacked solid-state batteries, the IPI electrolytes are directly cast on the LCO cathode layer by layer, and a cathode-supported IPI electrolyte is obtained. The fabrication process is shown in Fig. S7, and the details of preparation are also provided in the experimental section. It is well known that the surface of dry LCO cathode prepared by solution-casting method is usually rough and there are many invisible pores inside. The in-situ prepared IPL interlayer not only acts as a separator between LCO cathode and PLL electrolyte, but also can penetrate and fill the pores inside the cathode to construct a fast ionic conducting network in the composite electrode, as shown in the schematic diagram of LCO/IPI/Li cell (Fig. 4 e). This clever design is beneficial to improve the battery performance. Fig. 4a and b compare the rate performance of the LCO/Li cells assembled with different electrolytes, tested in voltage range of 3.0–4.3 V and 3.0–4.5 V. Obviously, the cells with IPI electrolyte display better rate performance in form of enhanced capacity and better reversibility than the cells with PLL electrolyte. The LCO/IPI/Li cell in Fig. 4a delivers capacities of 143.2, 111.5 and 55.2 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, 0.5 C and 1 C (1 C = 140 mA g−1) in the voltage range of 3.0–4.3 V, respectively. When the charging cutoff voltage increases to 4.5 V, the LCO/IPI/Li cell exhibits higher capacity as more Li+ are released from the lithium cobalt oxide, and the discharge capacities are 170.5, 134.4 and 57 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, 0.5 C and 1 C, respectively (Fig. 4b). The cycling performance of LCO/electrolyte/Li cells with voltage range of 3–4.3 V and 3–4.5 V at 0.2 C are also provided in Fig. 4c and d. And the LCO/Li cells assembled with IPI electrolyte exhibit high initial capacity of 144.3 mAh g−1 and 169.7 mAh g−1 at upper cutoff voltages of 4.3 V and 4.5 V respectively, and the corresponding capacity retention is 85.9% and 82.7% after 100 cycles at 0.2 C. It can be observed in Fig. 4f and g that the cell polarization remains stable at 4.3 V and increases slightly even at a higher voltage of 4.5 V during cycling. In sharp contrast, the LCO/Li cells assembled with PLL electrolyte display rapid capacity decay at both 4.3 V and 4.5 V, and the capacity falls to zero quickly. It is worth noting that the LCO/PLL/Li cells deliver extremely low coulombic efficiency (CE), which may originate from the continuous reaction between high-voltage cathode LCO and PEO-based electrolyte. Due to the accumulation of byproducts at the electrode/electrolyte interface, the charge and discharge curves of LCO/PLL/Li cells show increasing polarization during cycling until the batteries completely fails (Fig. 4h and i). When the cutoff voltage increases to 4.5 V, the PEO-based electrolyte suffers from more violent decomposition as more catalytic Co4+ are generated, thus faster capacity decay, lower coulombic efficiency and larger polarization are observed in LCO/PLL/Li cell. To find the underlying reason of battery failure, the evolution of the cell resistance before and after 100 cycles was further explored by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). As shown in Fig. 4k, the LCO/Li cell with PLL electrolyte exhibits a huge impedance change after cycling at 4.5 V, which can be ascribed to the accumulation of byproducts derived from electrolyte decomposition, and this result is in consistent with the charge and discharge curves in Fig. 4h and i. In contrast, only a slight impedance change can be observed after 100 cycles in LCO/Li cell with IPI electrolyte, demonstrating the excellent electrochemical stability of designed IPI electrolyte during long-term cycling. Therefore, the introduced IPL interlayer greatly improves the electrochemical performance of LCO/Li cells with PEO-based electrolyte at high voltage.

To further investigate the LCO/electrolyte interface and explore its effects on electrochemical performance, the morphologies of LiCoO2 before and after 100 cycles are characterized and shown in Fig. 5 . The pristine LiCoO2 particle presents a clean and smooth surface, as shown in Fig. 5a–c. After cycled in PLL electrolyte, a rough interfacial layer consisting of many fine particles formed by PEO decomposition can be clearly seen on the surface of the LiCoO2 (Fig. 5j–l). When the charging cutoff voltage increases from 4.3 V to 4.5 V, a thicker interfacial layer is observed on the surface of LiCoO2, as shown in Fig. 5m–o. The thickened interfacial layer may originate from the continuous and violent decomposition of PLL electrolyte as more highly oxidative Co4+ are generated at 4.5 V. The accumulation of decomposition products is primarily responsible for the increased interfacial resistance mentioned above, which is the root cause of the inferior electrochemical performance and rapid battery failure. In sharp contrast, the LiCoO2 particles cycled with IPI electrolyte at both 4.3 V and 4.5 V still present clean and smooth surface after 100 cycles, demonstrating that the prepared IPI electrolyte shows superior stability to LCO cathode at high voltage. These results reveal that the introduced IPL interlayer plays an important role in suppressing interfacial reactions and stabilizing LCO/electrolyte interface at high voltage, thus making it possible for the fabricated IPI electrolyte to work at high voltage.

The structural stability of LiCoO2 cycled with IPI electrolyte under different cutoff voltages was further verified by XRD. The phase of LiCoO2 after 100 cycles under 4.3 V and 4.5 V in Fig. S8 is in agreement with that of the pristine layered LiCoO2 powders before cycle, which further confirms the good compatibility of the IPI electrolyte with the high voltage cathode.

To investigate the electrolyte/Li interface, the Li anodes cycled with different electrolytes are characterized by SEM and XPS. The photographs and SEM images of Li anode after 100 cycles are shown in Fig. 6 . The Li anodes cycled with IPI electrolyte at 4.3 V and 4.5 V present a flat surface (Fig. 6a and e), and no lithium dendrite is observed, indicating a uniform deposit of lithium. However, the surface of the Li anodes cycled with PLL electrolyte at 4.3 V and 4.5 V is rough and damaged (Fig. 6i and m), which can be ascribed to the parasitic reaction between PEO-based electrolyte and Li. The chemical composition of the interfacial layer between Li and PEO-based electrolyte was further confirmed by TEM (Fig. S9), and the detailed analysis is provided in the Supporting information. These results demonstrate that the IPL interlayer plays a key role in stabilizing the lithium anode and can suppress the growth of lithium dendrites effectively during cycling.

Furthermore, XPS was conducted to explore the deep reasons why the IPL interlayer can stabilize the Li anode and confirm the components of the Li/electrolyte interface. The XPS results of Li anodes disassembled from different LCO/Li cells after 100 cycles are shown in Fig. 6. For the cells cycled with IPI electrolyte, two peaks of C 1s spectra (Fig. 6b and f) at 284.8 eV (C–C) and 286.3 eV (C–N) can be assigned to the absorbed PYR13 +, and the C 1s signal at 289.6 eV comes from Li2CO3. The –CF3 signal (292.8 eV) in C1s and F 1s (688.4 eV) spectra belongs to trapped TFSI−, and the signal at 684.6 eV can be assigned to LiF derived from decomposition of TFSI−. The O 1s spectrum exhibits three peaks of ROLi (530.9 eV), Li2CO3 (531.7 eV) and SO (532.6 eV), and the SO signal also corresponds to TFSI-. For the C 1s spectra of Li anodes with PLL electrolyte in Fig. 6j and n, there are four peaks located at 284.8 eV, 286.4 eV, 289.6 eV and 292.8 eV, which can be assigned to C–C, C–O, Li2CO3 and –CF3 signal [54], respectively. The C–C and C–O signals in cells with PLL electrolyte belongs to the residue of PEO electrolyte or its incomplete decomposition products, and the C–O signal is also observed in O 1s spectra (532.7 eV, Fig. 6k and o). The ROLi signal at 530.9 eV arises from the decomposition of PEO electrolyte. It can be observed from F 1s spectra that the surface of Li anodes cycled with IPI electrolyte generally show stronger intensity of LiF than Li anodes with PLL electrolyte, which is beneficial to reversible Li stripping/plating process. The LiF-rich interfacial layer may originate from the decomposition of high-concentration TFSI- in IPL interlayer and is primarily responsible for the stable electrolyte/Li interface during cycling.

In summary, we introduce an ionic-liquid-containing PVDF-HFP electrolyte as an interlayer at both PEO-based electrolyte/electrode interface and design a sandwich like IPI composite electrolyte through a facile solution-casting method. The IPL interlayer shows high ionic conductivity and good stability to Li anode as well as LCO cathode. After introducing the IPL interlayer, the serious interfacial reactions between PEO-based electrolyte and LCO cathode are significantly suppressed, and the IPL interlayer contributes to form stable electrolyte/electrode interface. Therefore, the LCO/Li cells with IPI electrolyte show superior electrochemical performance even at a high cutoff voltage of 4.5 V. The cells exhibit obviously improved cyclic stability than cells with PEO-based electrolyte. Also, the fabricated IPI electrolyte show excellent thermal stability. This study provides a novel strategy to design high-voltage solid-state Li metal batteries with PEO-based electrolyte.
